descriptionLinks: Calculate Electronic Band Gap via GW Approximation: https://docs.exabyte.io/tutorials/dft/electronic/gw-vasp-bg/
description: We illustrate in this animation how the results for a band gap computation on crystalline silicon can be further improved and made to be more accurate through the use of the GW Approximation.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: Band Gap via GW Approximation

youTubeCaptions.text: Band Gap via GW Approximation tutorial.
Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.

Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and select from the list the <sub alias='D1-GW zero-BG'>'D1-GW0-BG'</sub> workflow, whose naming convention is explained in the tutorial text linked under the video description.
We now explore the subworkflow structure making up the overall workflow.
First, try opening the 'SCF many bands' subworkflow, used to perform a calculation over a large number of unoccupied bands.

Then, open the only unit component, and inspect the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> input files displayed at the bottom. <break time='1.0' /> The <sub alias='N BANDS'>NBANDS</sub> tag sets the number of bands to a large value.

Let us also inspect the contents of the main GW step of the computation, by opening the <sub alias='G zero W zero'>G0W0</sub> step subworkflow. <break time='1.0' /> Again, let us review the <sub alias='WASP'>VASP</sub> input files.
The ALGO tag allows us to choose the <sub alias='G zero W zero'>G0W0</sub> version of the GW approximation, the simplest one.

After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. Here, we use one node with eight cores on the OR8 queue, because the GW method is quite computationally expensive.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. Here, we call it - Silicon Band Gap GW Calculation.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='3.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution.
The status of the calculation will change from pre-submitted to submitted, and then to active. Please wait, until the job has finished running. <break time='5.0' />
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results.
The band gap value can be found, at the bottom of the results page. Here, we can see the indirect gap, of about 1.094 eV, in excellent agreement with the experimental value for silicon.
